The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet the needs of the growing urban population. This study shows that the variability of maize production will increase substantially in the future, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase by a factor of 10 under 4 °C of global warming. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which different species of large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers, and grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, but dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of size-matched grazers. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off or furloughed workers, and that the majority are planning to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act loans. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of presolar silicon carbide grains is still a matter of debate. We show that the grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga, which is much older than the formation of the Solar System. The grains are parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium, which are up to 30 times larger than the analyzed grains. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun.

The ability to reproduce is the defining characteristic of all animals. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also the most limiting factor in the evolution of animals. We show that the ability to provide energy to the mother during pregnancy correlates with increased reproductive output. This effect is not due to an increase in resource availability, but rather an increase in metabolic power. This result has implications for the evolution of animals and the evolution of humans.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system, the basal ganglia, and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. We show here that the inflammatory protease caspase-1, which is activated in the brain in response to inflammation, is also able to cleave the C terminus of α-syn, leading to its aggregation. We also show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA by limiting the accumulation of α-syn aggregates. This would be of great importance, as there are no treatments available for MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues. It is the first line of defense against the blood and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells and is responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell that is constantly receiving information from multiple sources and must integrate this information to control the functions of the blood vessels. Here, we show that the endothelium is organized in a network that is effective in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a rich set of data on the COVID-19 pandemic, including many auxiliary signals that are not available elsewhere. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is a valuable resource for researchers and policy makers. We hope that it will be useful to the research community and to the public health community at large.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that a Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position is responsible for the loss of C-type inactivation gating and the inversion of the allosteric coupling. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter.

The role of the gut microbiome in human health is still being investigated, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the host. The hemoglobin system is a critical component of the oxygen transport system in the human body. The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of the effects of environmental change on biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We show that the evolution of the species flock is linked to the evolution of the climate, and that the lake level was a critical driver of the diversification of the fish species flock.

The evolution of technology is a fundamental process in human societies. The extent to which larger populations enhance the evolution of technology is a topic of great interest to both the social sciences and the physical sciences. We report the results of a large-scale experiment that investigates the evolution of technology in a population of 543 participants. We find that the size of the population does not enhance the cumulative cultural evolution of technology. This finding has implications for the study of the evolution of technology in the social sciences and the physical sciences. It also has implications for the study of the evolution of technology in the real world.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the APOE ε4 allele. APOE is a protein that is produced by astrocytes, a type of glial cell that is thought to play a role in AD. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which are the sites of AD pathology. We also suggest a possible mechanism for the increased risk of AD associated with the APOE4 allele.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere that is 1220 km in diameter and has a density of 12.0 g/cm3. It is the only solid sphere in the universe. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much easier than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. The use of marijuana is widespread, and its abuse is increasing. The effects of marijuana on the brain are not well understood. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine) is reduced in marijuana abusers, which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the human brain is uniquely adapted to process language. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language processing also capture the brain’s responses to language. This suggests that the brain and the machine are using a common mechanism to process language in the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a very successful paradigm in machine learning. However, it is still a black box, and it is not clear why it works. We show that the instability of DL is due to the fact that the training of DL is an ill-conditioned problem. We also show that the stability of DL is due to the fact that it is a well-conditioned problem. This is a fundamental result, which will have a significant impact on the future of machine learning.

The scientific community is currently engaged in a heated debate about the role of science in society. This debate is not only about the role of science in society, but also about the role of science in science.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the nerve-damaging disease leprosy, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a non-neuropathic form of leprosy. We have sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, and compared it with that of M. leprae. We find that the two species are remarkably similar, and that they have retained many of the same functions. This suggests that they are still able to cause disease, and that they may be able to cause disease in the future.

The dynamics of entanglement in isolated quantum systems is a central problem in the study of quantum information and thermodynamics. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be completely understood in terms of quasiparticles. This result is a major step forward in the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems, which is a long-standing challenge.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that requires a global response. The only live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine currently in clinical development, COVI-VAC, is based on recoded virus that is highly attenuated and can be manufactured at large scale. The vaccine is able to protect hamsters from lethal challenge with the wild-type virus, and the vaccine strain is able to replicate poorly in the lungs of hamsters. These properties make COVI-VAC a promising candidate for use in mass vaccination programs.

The Black Death, caused by Yersinia pestis, is one of the most devastating pandemics in human history. The disease led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has important implications for the history of the disease and for the spread of future epidemics.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in neuroscience. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is less understood. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the power of the nervous system. We also show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only dependent on the number of neurons but also on the number of synapses.

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the development of drugs that target the cell cycle is one of the most important advances in cancer therapy in the past 50 y. However, the development of new drugs is slow and expensive, and the identification of new targets is difficult. We have identified a new target for cancer therapy, and we have identified a new mechanism of action for a drug that is already in use for other purposes.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the dynamic actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cell differentiation. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF action is still poorly understood. Here, we show that ADF can induce a mechanical torque on the actin filaments it binds to, which enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical for the efficient severing of highly connected filament networks, such as those found in cell-cell junctions. Our findings have important implications for our understanding of the role of ADF in cell biology. They also suggest that mechanical forces may play a more important role in cellular processes, such as cell migration, than previously thought.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. Madagascar is a unique island, both in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We show that the human history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent settlement from Africa and Asia, and a strong influence of geography on the distribution of genetic diversity. These results have important implications for the settlement of the island, as well as for the study of human diversity and the evolution of human populations.

We show that the content of people’s Facebook News Feeds influences their emotions. When people see more positive content in their News Feeds, they post more positive content, and when they see more negative content, they post more negative content. This work suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook, and that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. This work also suggests that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of information for protein synthesis. In addition to the sequence of the mRNA, the presence of chemical modifications can have a profound impact on the rate of translation. In this study, we show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in the mRNA sequence can have a significant impact on the rate of translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings have implications for the rate of translation and the potential for mRNA modifications to impact protein synthesis. (Show more)

The evolution of aquatic lifestyles has been a major driver of the evolution of mammals. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically costly diseases in the world. The rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the ability of this virus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature is a major contributor to the severity of the common cold. This study demonstrates that the mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature, and that this temperature-dependent growth is dependent on the antiviral defense response of infected cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for the treatment of the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

In this study, we show that the type IV pili of the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa can be used as a sensor for the mechanical activity of the cell surface. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the role of type IV pili in bacterial motility and virulence, as well as for the development of new strategies to combat this pathogen.

In this study, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, which are the most abundant cervid in North America. We also show that the virus is circulating in deer during the winter, when human cases are rare. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary pathological hallmark. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is still debated. Here, we show that neurons, which are the main cell type affected in AD, are able to produce a variety of inflammatory factors, which are not observed in glial cells. These neuron-derived cytokines correlate with the extent of microglial activation and mobilization, even in the absence of extracellular plaques and cell death. Thus, we reveal the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis.

The domestication of the chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most important events in the history of human societies. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread at that site. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of RNA caps, which are required for the function of those molecules as alarmones. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove the cap of the messenger RNA in Escherichia coli, also has the ability to remove the cap of Np4-capped RNAs. This enzyme, which is inactivated by disulfide stress, is able to decape those RNAs, potentially affecting the adaptability of bacteria to stress. The unique manner in which capped substrates of this kind bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to treat sepsis, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function after sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is an effective strategy to increase arginine availability and restore T cell function and proliferation in a mouse model of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis.

The biomass of all living organisms is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere.

We present a model of self-organized criticality (SOC) in a continuous space. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

It is used in a variety of applications, including in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. However, it is not a perfect material, and it has some limitations. This work opens up new opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond, which can be used in a variety of applications.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the proteome of sperm, and that these changes are likely to be important for sperm function. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to researchers in the fields of reproductive biology, proteomics, and Drosophila genetics.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to the glycoprotein Ibα receptor on the platelet surface. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We show that the binding reaction can be switched to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health. The database is available for download and can be queried for the presence of viruses in a given sample. The database also provides information on the location of the viruses in the genome, as well as the number of reads that map to the virus. This information can be used to understand the impact of viruses on the human microbiome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process, which is difficult to be observed. We introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe the aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth today is inferred to be 15 °C, but the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past is unknown. We show that the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past was 65–80 °C.

Ion channels are the gates of the cell, and their opening and closing are the keys to the cell’s function. The opening and closing of ion channels are controlled by two types of gates, the activation gate and the inactivation gate. The activation gate is located at the intracellular end of the channel, and the inactivation gate is located at the selectivity filter. We found that the BK channel, which is a large-conductance calcium-activated potassium channel, has no classic activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 207 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2015. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) binds to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface and alters the biophysical properties of the cell. We show that this interaction reduces the energy barrier to invasion and thus increases the invasion efficiency of the parasite. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. The impact of humidity on the course of influenza infection is a topic of great interest. In this study, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases the severity of influenza virus infection. We also show that this increase in disease severity is due to a reduction in the host response to influenza infection. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the impact of humidity on influenza infection, and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat influenza infection. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this structure is weak. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the formation of syntactic structures is consistent with a tree-like structure, but that the brain also uses this information to merge words into phrases. Our results suggest that the brain uses a merge operation to compress syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in a wide range of biological processes. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness of the two forms of Axin, which may be important for the proper functioning of the Wnt signaling pathway.

The brain circuit that promotes overeating is not well understood. Here we describe a circuit that is critical for this process. We show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus, which is known to promote eating, is blocked by lesions of a specific group of neurons in the ventral tegmental area and the substantia nigra. These neurons are known to project to the lateral hypothalamus and inhibit GABA neurons in this region. We also show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus is not blocked by lesions of a second group of neurons in the ventral tegmental area, which project to the lateral hypothalamus and inhibit GABA neurons in the lateral hypothalamus. Finally, we show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus is blocked by lesions of a third group of neurons in the lateral hypothalamus, which project to the locus coeruleus and other regions. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

The ability of plants to fix nitrogen with bacteria is a fundamental process in nature, but it is not widespread in agriculture. One reason for this is that the bacteria are not under the control of the plant, and they can associate with other organisms, including pathogens. Here, we show that it is possible to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria, and we demonstrate that it is possible to engineer the bacteria to only fix nitrogen when in contact with the plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also represents a step toward the development of a synthetic nitrogen cycle in which nitrogen is fixed only when in contact with the desired host organism. This work is a major advance in the field of synthetic biology.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Data from monitoring records and community surveys provide evidence about how the program may affect forest outcomes. Community members perceived that the program’s monitors were new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ incentivized patrols were substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely community detection of and responses to deforestation. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals hear the world around them, and hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the wispy, wheel-shaped orb web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on the global community. The development of vaccines for this disease is a global effort, and the availability of affordable vaccines is critical for global access. Here we report the design of a recombinant protein subunit vaccine candidate that can be produced at large scale, with the potential to produce billions of doses annually. This vaccine candidate can be presented on a virus-like particle, which may further enhance the immunogenicity of the vaccine. This vaccine candidate may be a useful addition to the global response to COVID-19.

The study of the development of neural crest-derived tissues is of great interest for understanding the origin of human diseases. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK-like receptors are activated by secreted ALKAL proteins. Our results provide evidence for a role of ALKALs in the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex story that has been difficult to reconstruct. We present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes, which provide a detailed picture of the pathogen’s evolution and ecology during the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age. Our results suggest that the pathogen was not a direct descendant of Yersinia pseudotuberculosis, as previously thought, and that it was likely adapted to the flea vector. We also find evidence of a single lineage of plague that persisted for thousands of years, with rapid dispersal across Eurasia. These data provide insights into the early stages of plague’s evolution and help to understand the complex relationship between disease and human history. (Less)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. We found that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Donald Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies. The agricultural management of grasslands and croplands is a major driver of the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of native grasslands to cropland has led to the loss of 90% of the country’s native grasslands. In the last 20 y, the United States has lost 10% of its cropland, and the conversion of native grasslands to cropland has increased by 10%. This study shows that the management of grasslands and croplands can be used to sequester carbon in the soil.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a global system to detect and characterize emerging viruses and the threats they pose to human health. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize the highest-risk viruses, which can be used to inform the development of a global early warning system. We also created a web tool, SpillOver, that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to prioritize research and public health interventions. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used to inform global efforts to prevent and control future viral threats.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts animals, but the chemical basis for this trait is poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a new role for carbonic anhydrase in the chemistry of nectar, and demonstrate that the red color of the nectar is attractive to a vertebrate pollinator. This work provides evidence for the convergence of a color-based pollination system in two distantly related plants, and suggests that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation.

The history of Europe is marked by a series of migrations and invasions, which have shaped the genetic landscape of the continent. However, the processes that occurred during the period between the migrations of the Neolithic farmers and the Roman invasion are poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from southern Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 6th centuries AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of the individuals was shaped by a complex history, which included the migration of people from eastern Europe, as well as the introduction of artificial cranial deformation. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study provides insights into the processes that shaped the genetic landscape of Europe and the role of females in the shaping of the modern European genetic landscape.

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses are important for understanding the potential risk of bat coronaviruses to humans. Here, we report that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5, are different from those of the Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus. These results suggest that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses are important for understanding the potential risk of bat coronaviruses to humans. They also suggest that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses are important for understanding the potential risk of bat coronaviruses to humans. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses are important for understanding the potential risk of bat coronaviruses to humans. The global pandemic of COVID-19 has highlighted the need for rapid pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. Here, we describe the use of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) for pathogen surveillance in a resource-scarce setting in Southeast Asia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in a periurban population in Cambodia. Our findings highlight the feasibility of mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings and the need for coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This will enable rapid deployment of public health response. The data presented here will be made available to the global scientific community. The human genome is replicated in a discontinuous manner, with the synthesis of DNA lagging behind the replication fork. This process is known as DNA replication, and the lagging strand is synthesized in short fragments, known as Okazaki fragments. The synthesis of Okazaki fragments is catalyzed by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments, as it ensures that every nucleobase is faithfully replicated before the fragment is dissociated from the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp. However, the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. Here, we report the results of a series of kinetic experiments that provide a detailed understanding of the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. These results have implications for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments in humans. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA. In the laboratory, the evolution of life can be studied by in vitro evolution, in which the activity of a ribozyme is improved by selection. Here, we report the results of such an evolution experiment, in which we improved the activity of a ribozyme that catalyzes the replication of RNA. The improved polymerase ribozyme can now replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of life in the laboratory. (Show more)

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with the economic and demographic characteristics of the people who live there. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearances of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and demographic characteristics of the people who live there. This may be useful for policymakers and urban planners who are interested in improving the physical appearances of neighborhoods. The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are similar to those of other severe pneumonia, but the mortality rate is higher. The treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients is still in the stage of clinical trial. Tocilizumab, which has been approved for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, is a drug with multiple targets, which can reduce the production of inflammatory cytokines, and may be a potential treatment for severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal, and the maintenance of sufficient but nontoxic pools of copper is a fundamental challenge for all organisms. The ability of fungi to bind copper and to use this property to mediate interactions with competing microbes is a fundamental aspect of their biology. The existence of a copper-binding isocyanide biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests a previously unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides a model for the evolution of a copper-binding natural product in fungi and the potential for the use of these compounds as antimicrobial agents. This work also provides a model for the evolution of a copper-binding natural product in fungi and the potential for the use of these compounds as antimicrobial agents. (Show more)

The formation of tridymite, a high-temperature polymorph of SiO2, on Mars is a surprising discovery. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit, and the fact that it formed at a relatively low temperature, suggests that the source of the SiO2 was a high-temperature source, such as a silicic volcanic deposit.

Frost is one of the most important abiotic factors that limit the distribution of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new conditions. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

The Th17 cell lineage is central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease are not well understood. Here we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, we show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. We report a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes, which are the cells that control the function of motor neurons. This method enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that alleviate toxicity of astrocytes derived from ALS patients. This will accelerate the development of therapies for ALS. This method can be used to study other neurodegenerative diseases that are caused by astrocyte-derived toxicity. The gut microbiota of ticks is a complex community that is critical for the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which is a protein that is expressed by many arthropods and is known to alter the permeability of the gut barrier. We also show that iafgp alters the structure of the gut microbiota, which is critical for the ability of Anaplasma to colonize the vector. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota of their vector and suggest that targeting the gut microbiota of vectors may be a promising strategy for the control of vector-borne diseases. Birds are one of the most successful animal groups on Earth, and the study of their evolution is fundamental to understanding their diversity and biology. This study describes a new species of early bird, which adds to our understanding of the evolution of the avian tail and the origin of the modern avian body plan.
We show that the stratosphere is a major contributor to the climate system, and that it is important to understand the role of the stratosphere in climate.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are green. The color of a vertebrate is determined by the absorption of light by pigments in the skin, such as carotenoids, and by the color of the bones, which are often green. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the color of the animals is determined by the absorption of light by a class of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is the oxidized form of the protein-building block, the amino acid, lysine. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of green color in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This study also presents evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, a phenomenon that is widespread in vertebrates.

Cancer is a disease of the tumor microenvironment, and the hypoxic tumor microenvironment is a major driver of cancer progression. We report here that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the proportion of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs). ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the action of hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1α and HIF-2α, and is required for the induction of BCSC markers and the BCSC phenotype. ALKBH5 expression is also induced by the mTOR pathway, which is activated in response to hypoxia. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment is a mechanism by which the proportion of BCSCs is increased, and may contribute to the development of resistance to therapy.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. We report a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This will allow insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Less)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the presence of inflammation in the intestinal mucosa. IBD is a major health problem, and the current treatment is limited. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the intestinal inflammation process. We also found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD treatment. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD treatment. (Show more)

The spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in the open and closed conformations and show that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation. This may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The study of the chemical properties of matter under pressure is of fundamental importance, and it is also of great interest for applications in the fields of catalysis, energy, and the environment. We show that the chemical properties of matter change under pressure, and we provide a predictive model for the behavior of these properties.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of extreme events, including fire. However, the role of human ignitions and fire suppression in driving fire regimes is poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography can have a strong influence on fire activity, and that this can offset some of the warming caused by climate change. Our results highlight the importance of active management in reducing the risk of more extreme fires in the future.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is strategically timed to occur only at night, when the symbiotic organ is at its most stable. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbioses, and may have implications for the study of other animal–microbe interactions.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a sparse representation of an embedding space to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent topics. We then use a generative model to infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains. It can also be used to identify the gender bias of topics. Our method can be applied to any corpus of text. It is not limited to a specific domain or language. It can be applied to any language.

The second plague pandemic, which started in the 14th century, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We show that this understanding is incomplete. We demonstrate that the Black Death was the consequence of multiple introductions of the bacterium into European harbors, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y between each introduction. We also show that the disease did not establish itself in European rodents, and that the climate was not the cause of the failure of the second plague pandemic.

Asteroids are a group of organisms that have been described as “living fossils” because of their evolutionary similarity to the first organisms on Earth. In recent years, a disease has been observed in populations of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. This disease is characterized by rapid death, loss of turgor, and loss of limbs. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted by starfish. This study provides evidence that asteroids are living organisms, not inanimate rocks, and that they can be affected by disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island, both in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We show that the human history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent settlement from Africa and Asia, and a strong influence of the geography on the genetic diversity. This study also shows that the human history of Madagascar is not only unique, but also complex, and that the island is not a simple mirror of the human history of Africa.

Bacteria are able to sense and respond to changes in their environment. One way they do this is by regulating the expression of genes. In addition, bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) that can regulate gene expression. We report here the discovery of a small RNA that encodes a protein that interferes with the ability of another sRNA to regulate the expression of two genes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to reduce the burden of COVID-19 by increasing the availability of effective therapeutic options. Our approach can be extended to other protein molecules, such as vaccines, and may help to reduce the burden of other emerging infectious diseases. This work may also help to reduce the burden of other emerging infectious diseases.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of the agricultural community, and their assessments are critical for the management of agricultural production. However, the information they provide is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily integrated into quantitative models. We show that the US Department of Agriculture Crop Progress and Condition survey, which has been collecting crop assessments for over 30 y, can be used to derive a continuous, probabilistic measure of crop status. This index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be easily extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the impact of climate change on crop production.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports memory for linguistic information. We show that the dynamics of a simple model of the brain can support memory for several seconds. This memory is not dependent on synaptic plasticity or persistent activity, and it is not necessary to maintain a high firing rate. Instead, information is stored in the dynamics of the membrane potential, which are read out and used for processing. This work provides a computational neurobiology of language that can be extended to other domains of memory and information processing. It also provides a framework for understanding the role of the brain in language and other forms of communication.

Soil respiration is a major source of carbon dioxide (CO2) to the atmosphere, and its response to climate change is of great interest. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, and the results have been inconsistent. Here, we present a synthesis of the largest global dataset of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, and show that the response of soil respiration to warming is not consistent across biomes. Our results suggest that soil respiration may not increase uniformly with warming, but rather may decrease at higher temperatures, which may have important implications for the global carbon cycle.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the evolution of life on Earth. It is also one of the most challenging to model, because of the complexity of the ecological and evolutionary processes involved. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a key feature of the evolution of some of the most successful groups of organisms on Earth, is linked to a gradual relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water resources in South Africa and elsewhere. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also highlight the importance of regional-scale studies to understand the impact of climate change on water resources. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the “Trinity test,” in 1945, was a major event in the history of science. The discovery of a new quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the only material from the test that survived, is a major event in the history of science in the 21st century.

Photosynthesis is the basis of life on Earth. The oxygenic photosynthetic organisms are the plants, algae, and bacteria that use (bacterio)chlorophylls as their light-harvesting pigments. The biosynthesis of these pigments is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth isocyclic ring, the so-called isopterope, is a key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls. This reaction has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. Here we describe the evolution of the isopterope cyclases in oxygenic photosynthetic organisms. We also describe the discovery of a new protein, BciE, that is required for the formation of the isopterope in alphaproteobacterial (phototrophic) bacteria. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the isopterope cyclases. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and it is well known that neuroinflammation is associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the progression of MS. However, the molecular mechanisms of neuroinflammation in MS are not fully understood. In this study, we found that ASK1, a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, plays a critical role in the progression of neuroinflammation in EAE. We also found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the progression of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may provide a new direction for the treatment of MS. Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we show that the reversal-learning task, which is a measure of behavioral flexibility, is a converging target of the autism-risk genes. These autism-risk genes all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which resulted from the inability to forget. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the etiology of autism and for developing new treatments. (Show more)

The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and mutations in its components result in a variety of severe diseases. Here, we report the identification of two new disease-causing mutations in the components of the CRAC channel, STIM1 and ORAI1, and show that they have different functional consequences. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular basis of CRAC channel dysregulation, and suggest new therapeutic approaches for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. The study of the spread of disease-causing proteins in the brain is a major challenge in neurodegenerative diseases. Here we show that the spread of polyglutamine-expanded huntingtin in Drosophila is non–cell-autonomous, and that this spreading is associated with the internalization of aggregates and their accumulation in other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the study of the spread of disease-causing proteins in the brain and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The study of the immune system of bats is of great interest to the scientific community because of the potential for viruses to spillover from bats to humans. In this study, we identified a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and demonstrated that this protein is a potent immunomodulator. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of the immune system in bats and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of viral diseases in humans. Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon units provided by the folate cycle. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme that converts serine to a one-carbon unit, and have shown that this inhibition blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We have also shown that the one-carbon unit donor formate is a potent rescue of the inhibitor, but that this rescue is defective in a subset of cancer cells. This finding has implications for the treatment of cancer, and for the design of drugs that target the folate cycle.

The presence of proteins that are supersaturated in the brain and spinal cord of patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a phenomenon that has been observed in other neurodegenerative diseases. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. We observe that the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. The photonic crystals are predicted to produce exotic atom–light interaction behaviors, including suppressed spontaneous decay, photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal, and atom–light interactions that are anisotropic in the plane of the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The origin of the flowering plants is a major topic in plant science. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, has led to a new understanding of the origin of the flowering plants.

The study of ancient viruses is important for understanding the evolution of viruses, which are the most abundant form of life on Earth. Here we present the first ancient human parvovirus B19 (B19V) sequences, which date to ∼12.6 kya. We also show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype. These results show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time and that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change. We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with climate models. The acceleration is not due to changes in the rate at which the Earth is warming, but rather to changes in the rate at which the Earth is responding to the warming.

Pain is a normal part of life, but it is not normal that pain is increasing with age in America today. We show that pain prevalence has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a more general erosion of the middle class.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of enzyme active sites has the potential to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the enzyme-substrate complex, including the location of hydrogen atoms, the tautomeric states of functional groups, and the location of water molecules. Here, this approach is used to characterize the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a drug that was developed for the treatment of Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in the context of a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS. It may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great benefit to the global community.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to control the composition of their microbial communities. In this study, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts through the strategic delivery of a single glycan. We also show that the catabolism of this glycan is required for the maintenance of the symbiont population, the production of light, and the acidification of the symbiotic crypts. This glycan may therefore be used as a tool to control the activities of specific symbionts in other animal–microbe systems.

DNA alkylation is one of the major causes of DNA damage and is a major contributor to the development of cancer and other diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the stalling and mutagenesis of pol II are dependent on the RNA polymerase II fidelity checkpoints. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered MERS viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis is a determinant of MERS-CoV tropism, and may be a target for therapeutic intervention.

The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the global population have a significant impact on the environment, and the food system is responsible for 37% of global greenhouse gas emissions. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria by 50% led to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8% and a proportional decrease in meat meal sales of 14.5%. These results provide robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. Our results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering settings could have a significant impact on the environment and population health. This study provides a clear example of how nudging can be used to change people’s behavior in a way that is likely to be sustainable and scalable. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We report here a quantitative proteomics approach to the surfaceome, and a complementary glycoproteomics approach to the glycoproteome. We find that the surfaceome of a cancer cell line expressing a specific oncogene is remarkably similar to that of a normal cell line, but the functions of the surfaceome are harmonized by common biological themes. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or the outcome of the election. Vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the world. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is unique in its ability to form a covalent disulfide-linked dimer. This structure provides insight into the molecular basis for the unique properties of the protein, which may contribute to the severity of the disease. The structure also provides a framework for the design of future therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, which is a life-threatening condition. However, the mechanisms underlying this condition are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated, at least in part, by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1. This leads to an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex, which, in turn, leads to an increase in water influx into the cortex and cerebral edema. These findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies for this condition. (PsycINFO Database Record
